event.title: Tweed and Teviot have their confluence, and until 1975

data.event: It lies where the rivers Tweed and Teviot have their confluence, and until 1975 was part of the county of Roxburghshire.
The town has a population of 5,639 according to the 2011 census and based on the 2010 definition of the locality.
Kelso's main tourist draws are the ruined Kelso Abbey and Floors Castle, a William Adam designed house completed in 1726.

event.title: the creation of Kelso Abbey in 1128

data.event: The town of Kelso came into being as a direct result of the creation of Kelso Abbey in 1128.

event.title: was known as Calkou (or perhaps Calchfynydd) in those early days

data.event: The town's name stems from the fact that the earliest settlement stood on a chalky outcrop, and the town was known as Calkou (or perhaps Calchfynydd) in those early days.

event.title: the completion of the Abbey in 1128

data.event: A small hamlet existed before the completion of the Abbey in 1128 but the settlement started to flourish with the arrival of the monks.
